awd_titl_txt: RIDIR: Scalable Geospatial Analytics for Social Science Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a new body of spatial analytic methods for data intensive research in the social and behavioral sciences. Through an interdisciplinary team of geographic information scientists, public policy scholars, and computer scientists, this project provides researchers with the next generation of scalable, high performance spatial analytical techniques. The research targets existing challenges that have hindered the more extensive and intensive utilization of geospatial data from the US Census, American Community Survey, and social media through a combination of new computational algorithms for regionalization, new approaches to computational inference, and use of scalable spatial and spatiotemporal data management techniques. Research advances from this project will be integrated into new courses in data science, computer science, and public policy. Project results and materials will be disseminated in several ways including open source spatial analysis software repositories, tutorials and workshops for social scientists, and publications in scientific outlets.

The project's goals are to enhance the open source spatial analysis library PySAL in four main directions. The first innovation concerns new methods for the treatment of uncertainty in the American Community Survey data. Second, a new framework for statistical inference in the space-time analysis of segregation will be developed. Third, scalable algorithms for regionalization and spatially explicit aggregation of areal units will be produced. Finally, the project will develop a new scalable spatio-temporal data management layer to support the application of these three sets of analytics to large datasets.  The software developed here will be included in enhanced (and new) modules in PySAL. This will afford the development of new types of applications using different interfaces from plug-ins for desktop GIS, both open source and proprietary, to the development of software as service systems and the ability of installations where on-premise requirements are binding (Census Research Data Centers). This portfolio of use cases will support a wide range of scientific disciplines and will provide direct benefits to society through new geospatial tools that will improve the state of the art in urban planning, economic development, and spatial public policy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a variety of scalable geospatial analytics for social science research. Specifically, we focused on 1) new methods for the treatment of uncertainty in the American Community Survey (ACS) data; 2) a new framework for statistical inference in the space-time analysis of segregation; 3) scalable algorithms for regionalization and spatially explicit aggregation of areal units; and 4) a new scalable spatio-temporal data management layer to support the application of these three sets of analytics to large datasets. 

To address data uncertainty in the ACS data, we developed a generally applicable framework to integrate ACS data uncertainty into segregation measures as well as a method of statistical inference for comparative analysis. This framework can greatly facilitate ACS data users to incorporate data uncertainty into segregation analysis, leading to more reliable segregation pattern identification and better policy development. In addition, we proposed a new probabilistic approach to explicitly account for ACS data uncertainty in regionalization approaches, providing the capacity to identify a regionalization scheme with a degree of statistical certainty.

We have also designed and implemented a new framework for statistical inference in the space-time analysis of segregation. The new framework can derive computationally based inference for various segregation indices and is scalable to large data sets.

Regionalization is a fundamental spatial analytical method that aggregates spatial units into a set of contiguous regions. To address the computational complexity associated with regionalization and enable flexible regionalization requirements, we designed and implemented scalable and enriched max-p and p-regions regionalization algorithms that allow for a variety of aggregate-based constraints and objectives. In addition, we proposed novel spatial queries and devised scalable algorithms for spatial grouping of point and lines, and used them for scalable aggregation and overlay of points and polygons. These are achieved through a scalable spatio-temporal data management layer that are released as part of the open-source software outcomes of the project.

These new scalable geospatial analytics were implemented in three open-source python libraries to facilitate their use in social science research. The Python Spatial Analysis Library (PySAL) segregation package provides a suite of tools for measuring segregation over time and space. The PySAL spopt package provides a suite of tools for solving spatial optimization problems, including regionalization, facility location, and transportation-oriented solutions. The Pyneapple library provides scalable regionalization and grouping queries with a variety of user-defined constraints. In addition, it deceives a new framework to scale up Python-based algorithms that can be applied to many other algorithms within the social sceience data analytics ecosystem. 

In addition to the software described above, the project also supported the training of 6 postdoctoral scholars and 5 Ph.D. students, and training in spatial data science to diverse audiences at software workshops we delivered at scientific conferences.
